title: Construction contract risk identification based on knowledge-augmented language model
abstract:
Contract review is an essential step in construction projects to prevent
potential losses. However, the current methods for reviewing construction
contracts lack effectiveness and reliability, leading to time-consuming and
error-prone processes. While large language models (LLMs) have shown promise in
revolutionizing natural language processing (NLP) tasks, they struggle with
domain-specific knowledge and addressing specialized issues. This paper
presents a novel approach that leverages LLMs with construction contract
knowledge to emulate the process of contract review by human experts. Our
tuning-free approach incorporates construction contract domain knowledge to
enhance language models for identifying construction contract risks. The use of
a natural language when building the domain knowledge base facilitates
practical implementation. We evaluated our method on real construction
contracts and achieved solid performance. Additionally, we investigated how
large language models employ logical thinking during the task and provide
insights and recommendations for future research.

Abstract 
 
Contract review is an essential step in construction projects to prevent potential losses. 
However, the current methods for reviewing construction contracts lack effectiveness 
and reliability, leading to time-consuming and error-prone processes. While large 
language models (LLMs) have shown promise in revolutionizing natural language 
processing (NLP) tasks, they struggle with domain-specific knowledge and addressing 
specialized issues. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages LLMs with 
construction contract knowledge to emulate the process of contract review by human 
experts. Our tuning-free approach incorporates construction contract domain 
knowledge to enhance language models for identifying construction contract risks. The 
use of a natural language when building the domain knowledge base facilitates practical 
implementation. We evaluated our method on real construction contracts and achieved 
solid performance. Additionally, we investigated how large language models employ 
logical thinking during the task and provide insights and recommendations for future 
research. 
 
Keywords: Large language models, Construction contract risk, Knowledge 
augmentation, Knowledge database

l

models during construction contract risk identification. 
l

integration of vectorized domain knowledge into large language models.

facilitates its practical implementation.

1. 
Introduction 
Construction contracts are the foundation for relationships among project 
stakeholders, protecting their rights and interests throughout the project's lifespan. 
Contractual risks remain a long-standing and significant concern for all parties involved 
in a construction project, and failure to identify these risks in the contract clauses may 
result in disputes, posing a risk of project loss. According to a recent report (Victoria et 
al., 2022), the global average values and durations of disputes are $52.6M and 15.4 
months, respectively.  
Contract review involves several important tasks, such as identifying and modifying 
ambiguous clauses (Artan Ilter and Bakioglu, 2018), clarifying vaguely stated 
requirements (Hassan and Le, 2020; ul Hassan et al., 2020; ul Hassan and Le, 2021), 
and correcting inaccurately referenced specifications (Hamie and Abdul-Malak, 2018). 
Currently, the construction industry mainly relies on manual review due to the lack of 
sophisticated and reliable automated methods for identifying construction contract risks 
(CCRI). However, studies (Lee et al., 2019; Moon et al., 2021) have shown that this 
labor-intensive approach is error-prone and time-consuming.  It heavily relies on the 
expertise and experience of contract experts who have to review numerous contract 
clauses within a limited timeframe. 
Many researchers have suggested various methods that utilizes computer to aid the 
review process, which primarily involves rule-based natural language processing (NLP) 
methods (Kim et al., 2020) and machine learning (ML) algorithms (Choi and Lee, 2022) 
(Canda≈ü and Tokdemir, 2022). However, due to the complex language comprehension 
required for reviewing contract clauses, the existing approaches each suffer from 
different limitations. For instance, rule-based NLP requires comprehensive rules to pre-
defined, which is not only inflexible but also poses a significant challenge to cover all 
situations (Hassan and Le, 2021). In the case of applying ML algorithms (e.g., support 
vector machine), it requires a substantial amount of high-quality data to train a model 
for a specific task. This demands considerable time investment for training, as well as 
data collection, cleaning, and labeling. Meanwhile, its inability to effectively capture 
semantic and contextual information significantly limits the performance of text 
understanding and processing (Hassan and Le, 2021; Yang et al., 2022). 
To mitigate these problems, researchers have proposed the application of language 
models (LMs), to enhance the capture of semantic information from contract text 
(Mohamed Hassan et al., 2022; Shuai, 2023). For example, Fu‚Äôs research team (Fu et 
al., 2023) fine-tuned a language model, DeBERTa, for construction contracts semantic 
annotation. Meanwhile, due to the emergence of LLMs and their distinct performance, 
e.g., in-context learning, improved text comprehension, and the ability to summarize 
long paragraphs (Zhao et al., 2023), researchers have begun to consider the use of LLMs 
for processing contract text. Xue et al. (Xue et al., 2022) used BART to summarize 
construction contracts, maintaining critical information for better interpretation of the 
contracts. 
However, LLMs pre-trained in the general domain are not directly applicable for 
domain-specific tasks. As highlighted in several studies, using LLMs in specialized 
fields often leads to poor performance due to diluted domain-specific training data and 
issues that arise during the training processes (Ji et al., 2023; Kim et al., 2022; Mialon 
et al., 2023; Peng et al., 2023). Imperfect representation learning is one such issue, 
where the encoders learn incorrect correlations between different parts of the training 
data, leading to erroneous generation that deviates from the input. Similarly, direct 
application of LLMs to process construction contracts may lead to unprofessional and 
incorrect outputs, i.e., hallucination (Huang et al., 2023). As a result, the utilization of 
LLMs in the construction contract management field is not as widespread as in many 
other fields (Cui et al., 2023). 
Motivated by the aforementioned challenges and aiming to explore how to enhance 
LLMs to more closely emulate human experts for CCRI, we have adopted the idea of 
augmenting LLMs with external knowledge (Gao et al., 2022; Guu et al., 2020; Peng 
et al., 2023). We refer to this external knowledge, usually acquired from domain experts, 
as the factual knowledge and the expert knowledge. In this paper, we introduce a novel 
knowledge-augmented CCRI methodology. It augments an LLM with factual 
knowledge and the knowledge of contract experts, without fine-tuning the language 
model. This significantly alleviates the hallucination phenomenon in domain 
knowledge-intensive task. This research provides insights for utilizing LLMs with a 
thinking paradigm similar to that of human experts in identifying contract risks. 
Simultaneously, this contributes to the body of knowledge in the automated contract 
review, which could substantially decrease the time spent on contract reviews and 
minimize risks during construction projects. Although we introduce this method in the 
context of identifying construction contract risks, it is a versatile approach that can be 
incorporated into a broad range of construction contract text processing and 
management tasks.  
2. 
Related works 
2.1 Natural language processing in construction contract 
NLP is an effective means for computers to understand and solve a wide range of 
tasks involving human language. Common applications include information retrieval, 
information extraction, text classification, text generation, question answering etc. The 
final goal of NLP is to enable human languages to be processed automatically by 
machines (Otter et al., 2019). In the past, many NLP methods and Machine Learning 
(ML) algorithms based on statistical and probabilistic calculations have been proposed 
and widely used to process and analyze text data. This field has become a popular area 
due to the large amount of textual data generated during construction projects in recent 
years (Ding et al., 2022; Yang et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2023). 
Construction contract review is a key subject of study in construction automation 
scenario. Automating general tasks such as contract quality review and identifying 
common patterns in contracts can improve efficiency and quality. The construction 
contract text processing can be divided into rule-based NLP and ML-based (Salama and 
El-Gohary, 2016). Clauses or relevant information extraction after pre-defined rule 
matching is a common pattern for rule-based NLP methodology (Al Qady and Kandil, 
2010; Liu et al., 2014; Zhang and El-Gohary, 2016). Lee et al. (Lee et al., 2019) 
developed a rule-based automatic model to detect contract clauses that disadvantage 
contractors and extract critical information automatically. They first define the risk 
clauses, construct a domain lexicon, and design information extraction rules to achieve 
the identification of risk clauses and extraction of relevant information. Lee et al. (Lee 
et al., 2020) proposed rule-based NLP to build a model containing text pre-processing, 
syntactic analysis, and semantic analysis for checking the omission of contractor-
friendly clauses in contracts. Despite the impressive results, the scalability of the 
method is hindered due to its dependence on the manual crafting of rules, which seems 
tedious and may not function efficiently with other standards contracts. Kim et al. (Kim 
et al., 2020) proposed a rule-based NLP approach applying syntactic rules to increase 
the accuracy of matching the Subject, Verb, Object (SVO) of each sentence and 
semantic rules to pre-defined risk categories for extracting potentially dangerous 
clauses from the contract documents. Padhy et al. (Padhy et al., 2021) suggested that 
using common phrases from exculpatory clauses as rules to extract exculpatory clauses 
in any contract, and eventually extract all clauses that contain one or more common 
phrases in the exculpatory clauses. The paper also stated that automatically extracting 
the desired clauses using ML requires a large amount of training data. 
Obtaining high-quality training data from construction contracts is time-consuming 
and labor-intensive. This is the reason for most of the rule-based NLP studies opt for 
such approach. Studies that construct corresponding rules can yield good results in 
terms of accuracy and interpretability. However, their dependence on predefined 
vocabulary and rules diminishes the flexibility of their application, suffer from the issue 
of poor generalization, where some knowledge is difficult to describe through rules, 
and it is both impossible and ineffective to develop all possible rules. Further, the high 
performance comes at the expense of considerable human effort. With the advancement 
in the construction industry, construction contracts are becoming increasingly complex. 
Consequently, the need for construction contract risk identification cannot be satisfied 
solely by pure NLP applications. Instead, further research should focus on pre-trained 
neural network models (Hassan et al., 2021). 
In respect to ML-based method, commonly used ML models include support vector 
machine (SVM) (Canda≈ü and Tokdemir, 2022; Hassan and Le, 2021; Lee and Yi, 2017; 
Ul Hassan et al., 2020; Yang et al., 2022), na√Øve bayes (NB) (Canda≈ü and Tokdemir, 
2022; Hassan and Le, 2021, 2020; ul Hassan et al., 2020), k-nearest neighbors (KNN), 
and hidden Markov model (HMM) (Canda≈ü and Tokdemir, 2022; ul Hassan et al., 2020; 
ul Hassan and Le, 2021). All of which have been applied simultaneously around the 
above-mentioned studies and compared in terms of performance. For instance, ul 
Hassan and Le (Hassan and Le, 2020) utilized ML to develop a dependable 
classification model with a recall of 95%. The model effectively distinguished between 
requirement and non-requirement text within contracts.  
With the advancement of deep learning (DL), this technic has also been used in the 
analysis of construction contract. Recurrent neural network (RNN) and long short-term 
memory (LSTM) have been employed for this purpose. RNN is used to train a model 
for DB requirement classification, and the research has yielded that the reliability of the 
classification depends on the text vectorization method (ul Hassan and Le, 2021). Choi 
and Lee (Choi and Lee, 2022) proposed to apply a bi-LSTM algorithm to train a risk 
level ranking (RLR) model to automatically analyze the key risk clauses in the 
invitation to bid (ITB) at the bidding stage. In addition, the study also mentioned that 
although the accuracy of text classification models has improved, it does not necessarily 
imply that the model comprehends the text at the same semantic level as a human would.  
Although ML methods offer flexibility and efficiency, most studies face a 
significant limitation of the availability of training data. Collecting high-quality data is 
crucial for training a competent model, but it poses a challenge, particularly with 
domain-specific documents such as construction contracts. This challenge is further 
amplified by the sensitive corporate data often contained within contract information, 
making it even more difficult to acquire of high-quality contract training data. Table 1 
lists some representative studies using rule-based NLP, ML-based, and DL-based 
method in processing contract textual data.

2.2 Knowledge augmented language model 
In recent years, LMs have made significant progress, due to the availability of 
extensive datasets and the improvement of computer power. This progress has greatly 
influenced the field of NLP, with the emergence of several notable LLMs1 such as GPT 
(Brown et al., 2020), LLaMa (Touvron et al., 2023). As the LMs have scaled up in size, 
they have demonstrated emergent abilities including in-context learning, step-by-step 
reasoning, and instruction following. These capabilities, which may not be as 
pronounced in smaller LMs, have enabled LLMs to excel in zero-shot and few-shot 
tasks. They have also showcased exceptional proficiency in more complex endeavors 
such as mathematical problem-solving, question answering (Zhao et al., 2023). Recent 
studies have highlighted the outstanding capabilities of LLMs on question answering 
and logic reasoning. The study (OpenAI, 2023) suggested that GPT-4 outperforms 
existing pre-train language models on all benchmarks, the highest accuracy up to 96.3%, 
for various question-answering and commonsense reasoning. Furthermore, LLMs have 
proven to be highly efficient on knowledge-intensive tasks and have even outperformed 
human experts in certain domains.  
Regardless of the distinguished performance of the LLMs, its limitations lead to 
phenomena such as ‚Äúmaking something out of nothing‚Äù. This is the reason why it has 
not been widely used in many specialized fields that require a high degree of 
professionalism and logical rigor, such as law. This phenomenon summarized as 
hallucination. Hallucination can be categorized as intrinsic and extrinsic according to 
their nature (Liang et al., 2022). In current research, many methods have been proposed 
to alleviate this problem, including fine-tuning, prompt engineering, and data 
augmentation.  
Fine-tuning is a straightforward and highly effective method of addressing the 
hallucination, as it involves training the model with the knowledge of a specialized 
domain and tailoring it to suit the desired application (Huang et al., 2023; Thoppilan et 
al., 2022; Tinn et al., 2023). For instance, both the Lawyer LLaMA (Huang et al., 2023) 
and the ChatLaw (Cui et al., 2023) fine-tuning the LLaMA model by injecting legal 
domain knowledge including relevant law articles related to legal issue. These 
modifications successfully overcame the models‚Äô inability to leverage the legal 
knowledge to resolve domain-specific issues. However, fine-tuning a language model, 
particularly one with a large number of parameters, is not a trivial and costly task. 
Hence, to leverage the robust capabilities of the LLMs, studies suggested that 
specialized methods of prompting are required to guide them in recalling the knowledge 
they encapsulate, a process referred to as prompt engineering. In addition, the LLMs 
have also shown the abilities to tackle reasoning problems by specific instructions like 
Chain-of-Thought (Wei et al., 2022), Tree-of-Thoughts (Yao et al., 2023).  
The data augmentation on the other hand, also known as knowledge augmentation,

is a method that incorporates external knowledge to improve the LLMs understanding 
and generation capabilities. Recent works have explore leveraging the structure data in 
the form of knowledge graph (KG), providing external knowledge to the LLMs for 
inference and interpretability. Some researchers have proposed to incorporate KGs into 
LLMs during the pre-training stage, which can help LLMs learn knowledge from KGs 
(Liu et al., 2021; Yu et al., 2021). Others researchers proposed retrieving knowledge 
from the KGs for LLMs during the reasoning stage (Sen et al., 2023; Hu et al., 2022). 
Given the KGs are challenging to construct and continuously evolving, they pose 
difficulties for existing methods aimed at generating new facts and representing 
knowledge. Consequently, there are studies representing knowledge using vector 
embeddings that retain semantically meaningful information (Minaee et al., 2021).  
Vector embeddings represent data points in a multi-dimensional space and are 
commonly used in ML to characterize features of objects, such as text, images, or even 
entities. It typically consists of a set of numbers that form a multidimensional numerical 
space, wherein each dimension of a vector represents a different feature or attribute. 
For example, in textual data, one dimension might represent the frequency of 
occurrence of each word. By defining different features, it is possible to represent 
textual data as multi-dimensional vectors. This representation has the advantage that 
similar content will be closer in the vector space, so that similarity calculations, such 
as cosine similarity, can be used to quantify the similarity of the vectors. Compared 
with KGs in terms of semantic search, the vector similarity search, which locates 
vectors closest to a given query vector, offers more accurate and contextualized 
searching over data. Studies have started to use vector embeddings to represent and 
retrieve external knowledge in an effort to improve the performance of language model 
(Lazaridou et al., 2022; Nye et al., 2021). Peng et al. (Peng et al., 2023) proposed an 
LLM-augmenter, which utilizes similarity search to retrieve external knowledge from 
Wikipedia, and links the retrieved knowledge to the relevant context. They reported that 
the augmenter significantly improves the factuality of the answers. He et al. (He et al., 
2022) used Wikipedia as an external knowledge base, applying cosine similarity to 
select the passages most similar to the input query sentences as knowledge relevant to 
the question. The results of the study show that incorporating additional knowledge 
surpasses methods that do not. This superiority is evident in terms of common-sense 
reasoning and temporal reasoning, and the faithfulness of the responses increases 
dramatically, especially as the scale of the model increases. Knowledge is critical for 
equipping statistics-based models, and vector embeddings can facilitate the 
development of an efficient retrieval enhancement system. Capitalizing on efficient 
semantic search capability, this study proposes a novel method for identify risks in 
contract clauses by incorporating knowledge highly relevant to the risk clauses into 
LLMs, not only aligning the models‚Äô behaviors with the preferences of human experts 
enables but also increasing trustworthiness of the answers provided by the LLMs. As a 
result, enhances its capabilities to identify risks in contract clauses. 
 
3. 
Methodology 
In this section, we introduce the knowledge augmented language model based CCRI 
methodology. It consists of four parts: building a domain-specific knowledge base, 
retrieving project clauses, retrieving clause-review pairs, and developing appropriate 
prompts. Given a construction contract clause, the goal of CCRI is to identify 
contradictions or omissions in the context based on a given checkpoint. The overall 
architecture of our approach is depicted in Fig. 1. 
Fig. 1. The framework of knowledge augmented LLM for CCRI. 
3.1 Constitution of domain-specific knowledge base 
The storage of data is one of the key tasks. Before storing the contract text into the 
knowledge base, it needs to be vectorized. To ensure the effectiveness of semantic 
search, the text should be parsed into text chunks with similar attributes. In the context 
of the construction contracts, the text is parsed into chunks based on the content of the 
clauses, specifically, each section. For instance, the content of "condition precedent" 
and "payment" will be treated as two separate text chunks. Longer sections can be 
divided into shorter paragraphs while maintaining semantic coherence. Each chunk is 
then vectorized using a text vectorizer, represented as an n-dimensional vector of 
floating-point numbers. The vectorized text chunks and their corresponding 
embeddings are subsequently stored in the knowledge base. 
The organization of data for the two knowledge bases is illustrated in Fig. 2. Each 
knowledge base is designed for specific purposes and has unique schemas. Both 
knowledge bases contain an "ID" and "Embeddings". The "ID", an integer number, is 
the primary key for each row of data, while the "Embeddings", a floating-point vector 
denotes the vector representation of each clause. The project clause base is responsible 
for storing and providing contract clauses for risk identification. It adds the fields 
"Clause_type" and "Clauses" to its schema. "Clause_type" records the type of clause, 
specifically the name of the section (when the subsection is omitted) or the subsection 
of each clause. "Clauses" represents the detailed content of each clause. For example, 
in subsection 4.1 "Condition Precedent", "4.1 Condition Precedent" is the 
"Clause_type" and the corresponding clauses "The Contract shall come into full force 
and effect on the Date‚Ä¶ waived by the Owner" are the "Clauses". The "Embeddings" 
are then the vector representations of the relevant clauses. On the other hand, the expert 
knowledge base is responsible for storing the risky clauses identified in past contract 
reviews, along with their review results. Its schema includes three fields: "Checkpoints", 
"Clauses", and "Reviews". "Checkpoints" stores the contract risk identification 
requirements of an organization, tailored to different contract characteristics and risk 
preferences. Similar to the project contract base, "Clauses" stores specific clauses. 
However, these clauses are those that have been identified as risky in the past projects. 
"Reviews" records the results of the identification of such clauses, providing 
explanations as to why certain clauses are considered risky. 
Fig. 2. Process of building a construction contract knowledge base. 
 
It is essential to define the scope covered by these checkpoints, specifically 
delineating the key risk categories within the construction contract. In general, 
checkpoints should cover areas such as: Contractual Basics, Permissions and Transfers, 
Payment and Financials, Time and Schedule, Warranty and Performance, Liabilities and 
Penalties, Suspensions and Terminations, Site Condition, Claims and Variations, and 
Design and Subcontracting. Subsequently, based on the nature of the identification and 
task requirements, the composition of the checkpoints can be further specified. The 
extent of a checkpoint is determined by the nature of the check, which can be abstract 
or concrete, such as identifying specific amounts or dates. The final checkpoint is drawn 
based on the task requirements, which can be categorized into key point summaries, 
element extraction, and logical reasoning. For instance, an abstract logical reasoning 
checkpoint might state, "The conditions precedent should be waived by mutual 
agreement between the Project Company and the Contractor." Conversely, a concrete 
element extraction checkpoint might query, "What is the proportion of the advance 
payment?" The format of a checkpoint can differ, from declarative statements, as 
illustrated in the prior examples, to interrogative sentences, and within these sentences, 
it is vital to incorporate technical terms specific to the domain. 
In the expert knowledge base, there is a one-to-many relationship between 
"Checkpoints" and "Reviews", where a single checkpoint can correspond to multiple 
reviews. This is because, while the descriptions of clauses in different contracts may 
vary, these clauses may present similar risks. For clauses with the same risks, the same 
checkpoint is used to review these clauses. For example, if two risk clauses "8.1 
Commencement of Works; The Financial Closing has occurred in terms of the 
implementation agreement‚Ä¶" and "5.1 Notice to Proceed; The Commencement Date 
shall be the date stated in a written notice‚Ä¶" have been identified as risky for the same 
checkpoint "The Financial Closing Date shall have occurred before the Commencement 
Date" in different contracts, then these two risk clauses and their respective reviews 
will share the same checkpoint in the expert knowledge base. 
With respect to the composition of reviews, it can be structured into three main 
parts: 1. Conclusion; 2. Content of the relevant clauses; 3. Rationale. For instance, "A 
particular provision appears to be in conflict with the checkpoint. As per section 8.1 
titled 'commencement of works', specifically in sub-clause (a), it is mentioned that the 
obligation can be 'waived or deferred (with or without conditions) by the Employer', 
which prescribes that the Financial Closing should transpire prior to the 
Commencement Date. This implies that the requirement for the Financial Closing to 
precede the Commencement Date can be overruled by the Employer. Consequently, it 
is not definitively ascertainable that the Financial Closing Date will precede the 
Commencement Date." The review first directly provides a conclusion regarding the 
potential conflict between the clause and the checkpoint. Subsequently, it elaborates on 
the specific content of the relevant clause, and finally, it presents the basis for the 
judgement based on the clause's content. 
3.2 Project clauses retrieval 
Clause retrieval is a process designed to fetch project contract clauses that are 
highly associated with a given checkpoint from the pre-built project contract base (as 
depicted in Fig. 3). This process addresses the challenge posed by the fact that the 
clauses containing key information may be scattered across different locations, often 
involving cross-page situations. For example, Clause IV is a time provision that 
describes advance payment, yet the definition of advance payment is elaborated in 
Clause I. Clause I and Clause IV appear in different locations within the contract. The 
procedure begins with a manually collected checkpoint, derived from a set of checklists 
created by construction contract experts. These checklists focus on major inspection 
topics. For example, a checkpoint related to the inspection topic of ‚ÄúPrecondition of 
Commencement‚Äù might include statements such as ‚ÄúReceipt of advance payment is not 
one of the commencement preconditions‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Owner‚Äôs provision of right of access 
to the site is not one of the commencement preconditions‚Äù.  
Before searching for relevant clauses within the project contract base, the 
checkpoint undergoes vectorization using a text vectorizer, such as the sentence-
transformers model provided by Hugging Face (Reimers and Gurevych, 2019), or the 
text-embedding-ada-002 model provided by OpenAI2.  After vectorization, a semantic 
search is performed to retrieve the appropriate clauses. This involves calculating the 
vector similarity between the clauses and the checkpoint. The similarity metric can be 
based on either cosine similarity or Euclidean distance, both of which should yield the 
same ranking of results.  
 
Fig. 3. Process of retrieving factual knowledge and expert knowledge. 
3.3 Clause-review pairs retrieval 
This step aims to acquire the case clauses and their corresponding reviews from the 
expert knowledge base. The case clauses are risky clauses collected from the past 
project contracts and the reviews are statements explaining the reason. To retrieve the

search, on the expert knowledge base using the checkpoint and the retrieved project 
clauses. The checkpoint retains its original text format, while the retrieved project 
clauses are transformed into a vector representation, composed of long segment 
multiple clause i. As shown in Fig. 3, after retrieving top k project clauses associated 
with checkpoint, according to the order of the similarity scores, we merge all the clause 
i into a singular text and then vectorize it. 
To retrieve the case clauses relevant to the same checkpoint used to retrieve the 
project clauses, we first match the same checkpoint in the expert knowledge base. This 
narrows down the pool of clauses to those most pertinent to the checkpoint, ensuring 
that the retrieved case clauses possess the type of risk that the project clauses are 
potentially covering. After that, the top k case clauses can be retrieved by calculating 
the vector similarity between the project clauses and the case clauses. Finally, the most 
relevant case clauses and their reviews are extracted based on the similarity score. 
Consider the following example: when analyzing the checkpoint "The condition 
precedent should be waived by mutual agreement..." and the corresponding project 
clauses "The Contract shall come into full force and effect on the Date...", which 
provide some details regarding the financial close. There are four distinct case clauses: 
"The Employer may issue the Notice to Proceed at any time and the Commencement 
Date shall occur...", "The Commencement Date shall be the date stated in a written 
notice to the Contractor from the Employer...", "The Company shall issue an NTP if the 
Conditions Precedent are defined...", and "Commencement Date refers to the date when 
the Contractor receives the Notice to Proceed from the Project Company...". The initial 
two clauses pertain to the checkpoint "The Financial Closing Date shall have occurred 
before the Commencement Date", whereas the latter two are associated with "The 
conditions precedent should only be waived by mutual agreement between the Project 
Company and the Contractor". Since the project clauses include references to the 
financial close, it is evident that using vector similarity for retrieval will lead to the 
extraction of clauses connected to the financial close risks, specifically the first two 
clauses. Nevertheless, the risk present in these two clauses arises from the financial 
close itself, rather than the condition precedent being waived through mutual agreement. 
Consequently, these clauses fail to offer insights related to mutual agreement and 
therefore do not contribute to the language model's understanding of the core of the 
checkpoint. To this end, it is necessary to first match the case clauses that have similar 
risks to the project clauses based on the checkpoint using vector similarity calculation. 
At this point, clause-review pairs related to the checkpoint can be extracted as the expert 
knowledge to enhance the logical reasoning of the language models. 
3.4 Prompt development 
Different prompts for the same question can produce diverse answers, which makes 
it challenging to find the ‚Äúright‚Äù prompt to exploit the capabilities of the LLM. 
Leveraging the in-context learning capabilities of LLMs, we present a two-stage 
prompting process for generating robust, stable, and trustworthy results (as depicted in 
Fig. 4). The first step begins with a question-answering prompt. The content of the 
prompt is based on the information retrieved in the previous knowledge retrieval stages. 
Multiple distinct suggestions are generated by feeding the prompt into the LLM 
independently several times. In the second step, we use a zero-shot response selection 
prompt and adopt the idea of majority voting to select the most suitable and promising 
suggestion. The selection is based on the input context, including the checkpoint and 
specific conditions. This method employs self-consistent sampling rather than greedy 
decoding. It improves the accuracy of inference by generating a number of different 
answers and then applying majority voting. This response selection prompt is repeated 
multiple times independently, similar to the first step. The final answer for the risk 
identification is determined by the suggestion that receives the most votes.

4.1 Data preparation 
We adopted EPC contracts collected from construction projects as our test data. 
One hundred clauses are extracted from the sample contracts and used for testing on

required for the checkpoints. The first and second contracts contain 22 and 7 clauses,

5. Discussion 
The proposed method aims to develop an automatic pipeline for contract review 
and risk detection based on knowledge augmented LLM. We demonstrated the 
proficiency of our method with selected practical construction contracts. In order to 
adopt our method in contracts of a wider domain, we offer some insights and 
apprehensions that may arise during the implementation of the method in real-world 
scenarios. 
5.1 ‚ÄúLogical thinking‚Äù of LLM 
We observe from our experiment that accurate risk review conclusion comes with 
subtle human intervention. It is crucial to note that LLM has a higher tendency to follow 
the logical reasoning of human-provided demonstrations. Especially in contract review 
domain which requires higher level of alignment with experts, it is essential to carefully 
provide the demonstrations (clause-review pairs as in this paper). 
Based on our experimental observations, there are two primary factors influence the 
efficacy of providing the clause-review pair to the LLM in emulating the thinking 
pattern of the contract experts, namely the quantity of clause-review pairs and the 
degree of similarity between the case clause and the risk clause. Regarding the former, 
when the provided case clause closely resembles the clause that requires scrutiny, both 
a single clause-review pair and three pairs can prompt the LLM to emulate the expert's 
thinking pattern in assessing risk clauses, implying that the LLM will review related 
clauses based on similar risk preferences. We also observed that even if discrepancies 
exist in the risk rationale for the same checkpoint among multiple similar clause-review 
pairs, the LLM's ability to mimic the experts‚Äô thinking pattern remains. As for the latter, 
when only one clause-review pair is provided and the case clause within that pair is not 
highly similar to the risk clause needing examination, the clause-review pair does not 
sufficiently stimulate the LLM to adopt the appropriate analytical mindset. Taking 
clause 1 from the case illustration as an example, when a less correlated clause-review 
pair is provided and the Euclidean distance between the case clause and clause 1 is 0.31, 
the LLM fails to accurately identify the inherent risks in clause 1. This might be due to 
the provided clause-review pair emphasizes the risk arising from the absence of the 
description stating "The Financial Closing Date shall have occurred before the 
Commencement Date", rather than from the provision allowing the employer to waive, 
which results in the risk. 
 Risks in construction contracts frequently appear in sentences with such subtle 
descriptive variations. Identifying such risks requires the ability to apply specific 
knowledge to certain circumstances. It is important to note that while LLMs can mimic 
logical reasoning, they do not truly ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù or ‚Äúthink‚Äù about the topics the same 
way humans do. In the first example presented in section 4, the occurrence of the risk 
is related to risk preference, and the difference in responses depends on whether 
external knowledge of risk preference is provided. For a general language model 
without specific risk preferences, the first answer is reasonable. The risk of this clause 
lies in the preference level of "or" in "satisfied or waived." In the response utilizing our 
method, we provide a review pair with similar clauses. The clause-review pair, serving 
as knowledge enhancement, emphasizes the risk preference for "or" and highlights the 
risk caused by the uncertainty brought about by "or" to some extent.  
Humans excel at learning from examples. Confronted with an unfamiliar issue, we 
often reason and derive solutions by comparing it with familiar situations. The results 
of our method suggest that LLMs demonstrate a similar ability, leading some to 
postulate that they exhibit a form of  ‚Äúlogical thinking‚Äù. However, the perceived "logical 
thinking" of LLMs is merely a result of recognizing and generating patterns from a 
massive dataset. While they lack human-like cognition and reasoning abilities, they can 
emulate logical reasoning to a significant extent based on the data and the appropriate 
paradigm, namely the provided knowledge and the prompt (P. Liu et al., 2023). Just as 
data inherently sets the upper bound of a model's potential, the inclusion of informed 
professional analysis and well-defined risk preferences shape the judgment of a 
language model in risk identification. As a result, the construction of a comprehensive 
and precise knowledge base is fundamental to this endeavor. Furthermore, the 
continuous accumulation of risk-related clauses and expert analyses through practice 
contributes to sustainably performance improvement. 
Traditionally, supervised learning-based models predict outputs based on inputs. In 
contrast, prompt-based learning models use language models to predict the probability 
of a text sequence. In this new paradigm, the initial input undergoes transformation 
through a template, resulting in a "prompt" with unfilled slots. The language model then 
probabilistically fills these slots to obtain the final output. Such an approach, with well-
crafted prompts, enables the language model to flexibly perform few-shot or zero-shot 
learning, and even emulate "logical thinking." Therefore, for the language model to 
produce trustworthy and human-interpretable responses, prompts with sufficient 
context, clarity, and specificity are essential, particularly for highly relevant knowledge 
in downstream tasks. 
5.2 Evaluation criterion for CCRI tasks 
Although the risk review using our method can greatly improve the contract review 
efficiency, there doesn‚Äôt exist a comprehensive evaluation metrics for evaluating the 
LLM generated content for contract review task. The establishment of such evaluation 
metrics faces a major challenge due to the diverse and complex evaluation standard in 
real-world scenarios. 
Currently, the evaluation primarily relies on the feedback of human experts, using 
it as the ground truth. The expert assesses the response based on its logic, complexity, 
accuracy, and traceability. Specifically, they determine whether the response actually 
refers to the provided clauses, if its logic is sound, and if it accurately identifies the 
point of contradiction. To improve the efficiency of evaluations and mitigate the human 
subjective bias, one promising approach is to establish an iterative, automated expert 
evaluation system. Potential methods include using a knowledge graph for explicit 
knowledge inference (Zhang et al., 2020; Zheng et al., 2023). The identification results 
are compared with inference outcomes obtained from the knowledge graph, enabling 
the evaluation of answers generated by large language models from a logical inference 
perspective. On the other hand, it is also feasible to combine multiple language models, 
allowing them to serve as an evaluator that assesses answers for accuracy based on 
specific criteria. Answers that deviate from the standards, along with the corresponding 
adjustment strategies, are returned to the language models responsible for identifying 
risks, which then re-generate them. For instance, Yang‚Äôs team (Y. Liu et al., 2023) used 
the LLMs along with a particular prompting paradigm to act as the evaluator for 
assessing natural language generation outputs. Their results show that the proposed 
method outperforms all previous methods. Furthermore, the establishment of relevant 
benchmark datasets is crucial for comprehensive performance evaluation of these tasks. 
Examples of benchmark datasets in other domains can be referenced in the works of 
(Chalkidis et al., 2022). 
6. 
Conclusion 
The paper presents a knowledge augmented language model methodology for CCRI, 
which integrates construction contract knowledge into LLMs. This approach 
incorporates domain-specific knowledge, contract clauses, and expert reviews to 
improve the efficiency and accuracy of contract-specific knowledge retrieval.  The 
experiment results demonstrate the effectiveness of the method and provide valuable 
perspectives for discussion. 
While the presented method performs well in the experiment, it has not yet been 
implemented in real-world scenarios that may involve a larger domain knowledge base. 
On one hand, a larger knowledge base could enhance the language model's 
comprehension by providing more prior knowledge. On the other hand, it may pose 
challenges in identifying the best few-shot learning materials. Therefore, it is 
recommended to collaborate with industrial practitioners to further investigate this 
direction.
